title: President Harry S. Truman With USO Couple

title: President Truman Presents Congressional Medal of Honor to Francis J. Pierce
Scopenote: President Truman presents a Congressional Medal of Honor to Francis J. Pierce (second from left), former Pharmacists' Mate 1st Class, of Earlville, Iowa, at a ceremony in the White House Rose Garden. Lt. Comdr. Jackson Charles Pharris (left), retired, of Long Beach, California, and Staff Sgt. John R. Crews (right) of Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, are wearing the Congressional Medals of Honor they received at the same ceremony. All three were decorated for outstanding heroism during World War II. (See 77-577.) From: Pershing Tousley, Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.

title: General Jonathan M. Wainwright was presented with the Congressional Medal of Honor by President Truman
Scopenote: General Jonathan M. Wainwright being presented with the Congressional Medal of Honor in the Rose Garden at the White House on the occasion of General Wainwright's return to Washington after his release from imprisonment by the Japanese. The final stand on beleaguered Corregidor, for which he was in an important measure personally responsible, commanded the admiration of the nation's allies. (See also 66-1499-13.) From: Pershing Tousley, Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.

title: 35th Division in First World War
Scopenote: Terrain covered by the 35th Division in the First World War in the Battle of the Argonne.  The lower part of the picture is the German side of Vaquois Hill, a German stronghold for three years, the futile attempts to storm costing the French over 30,000 lives during that time.  The 70th Infantry Brigade, following an intensive all-night barrage, stormed and reduced the Hill by frontal assault the morning of September 26, 1918, continuing on to Cheppy and Charpentry the same day.  The farthest advance of the Division was Exermont, just above and beyond the top of the picture.

title: Photograph of Painting "Freedom United Washington and Simon Bolivar" by Benito Tomas
Scopenote: Photograph of an allegorical composition in art which underlies an important phase of vital interest, that of Pan-American solidarity.  The highlights of history recalling the noble sacrifices for freedom in North and South America are symbolized in a spiritual meeting of Washington and Bolivar under the title, "Freedom United Washington and Simon Bolivar."  The painting will be on exhibit at the Washington Square Outdoor Show in Greenwich Village, New York City, the week of May 25, 1952.  The photograph was sent to President Truman and has an original autograph as follows:  "In the Name of freedom - To the President of the United States, the Hon. Harry S. Truman - Benito Tomas - 1952."  Donor:  Benito L. Tomas.

title: James E. Petrillo and Harry S. Truman Playing Musical Instruments
Scopenote: James C. Petrillo, President of the American Federation of Musicians, shows off a few dance steps (right) while former President Harry S. Truman, standing before the piano, cheers him on.  They teamed up for three wild choruses of Hail, Hail, the Gang's All Here. The duet gave Mr. Truman a chance to test the concert grand piano presented to him by the Federation for the Truman Memorial Library in Independence, Missouri.  Later that day, Mr. Truman addressed the 57th annual convention of the Federation, which was held in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.  (See also photos 70-512, 58-160, and 69-0553.)  Original is an oversize 14" x 16" photo mounted on heavy card stock, filed in oversize file.  From:  Office of President Truman at the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: President Harry S. Truman on Aircraft Carrier USS Franklin D. Roosevelt
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman, in cap and leather jacket, (second from left) strides across the flight deck of Aircraft Carrier U.S.S. Franklin D. Roosevelt as Captain Charles T. Mauro, Charleston, South Carolina, points out a flight maneuver during Eight Fleet war games off the Virginia Capes. In the background, left to right, are Brig. Gen. Harry Vaughan, Presidential Military Aide, Captain Clark Clifford, Presidential Naval Aide, and John R. Steelman, Special Assistant to the President. The maneuvers were designed to give the President a close-up show of how carriers turned back Japanese fleets at Midway, Coral Sea, and the Philippines. This is an unretouched, cropped version of 68-1815, and is an oversize 14" x 16" photo on heavy card stock. From: Office of President Truman.

title: At White House, General Dwight D. Eisenhower with President Truman

Eisenhower met with President Truman in a highly-secret conference on military affairs and the speed-up of Western European re-armament. The General said he has no presidential aspirations "just now." (Similar to 78-569). This is a 14" x 16" oversize photo on heavy card stock. From: Office of President Truman.

title: President Truman shakes hands with Princess Elizabeth

This is a 14" x 16" oversize photo mounted on heavy card stock.  From:  Former President Truman's office at the Harry S. Truman Library.

From:  Office of President Truman.

title: Truman and Barkley at Democratic Convention
Scopenote: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania:  Convention Hall is in hysteria as the two men who will carry the colors of the Democratic Party into the presidential race, President Harry S. Truman (left) and Senator Alben Barkley, shake hands on the speaker's platform.  Sam Rayburn, permanent chairman, is on the right.  (Same as 77-3548 except uncropped)  This is a 14" x 16" oversize photo mounted on heavy card stock.  From:  Office of President Truman.

title: President Truman Speaking at the Democratic National Convention
Scopenote: Both arms raised, President Truman blasts the G.O.P. as he delivers his acceptance speech before Democratic National Convention delegates at Convention Hall in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.  Senator Alben Barkley, nominated for Vice-President, sits behind the President on the left.  (Similar to 59-1530, 64-480-1/7, and 92-72-1)  This is a 14" x 16" oversize photo mounted on heavy card stock.  From:  Office of President Truman.

title: President Truman visits Mexico
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman places a wreath at the base of the monument to the "Heroes of Chapultepec," in memory of Mexican war dead during his visit to Mexico.  He is the first U. S. President to visit our southern neighbor while in office.  A printed message to Mr. Truman on the photo reads;  "They, too, were present in this second that changed the history of two nations.  Enrique Diaz"  (See also 69-361 and 66-3165.) This is a 10" x 13" oversize photo mounted on card stock.  From:  Office of President Truman, found in locked credenza of his desk.

title: President Truman visits Mexico
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman can be seen (in the lower left-hand corner) behind a wrought-iron fence after placing a wreath at the base of the monument to the "Heroes of Chapultepec," in memory of Mexican war dead during his visit to Mexico. He is the first U. S. President to visit Mexico while in office. The other persons are unknown. (See 69-361 and 66-3165.) The original is a 10" x 13" oversize photo mounted on card stock. From: Office of Harry S. Truman, found in locked credenza of his desk.

title: President Truman in Mexico
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman can be seen on the right side of this photo, facing the press after placing a wreath at the base of the monument to the "Heroes of Chapultepec," in memory of Mexican war dead during his visit to Mexico. He is the first U. S. President to visit Mexico while in office. The other persons are unidentified. (See also 69-361 and 66-3165.) The original is a 10" x 13" oversize photo mounted on card stock. From: Office of President Truman, found in locked credenza of his desk.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman, Margaret, and Clifton Daniel
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (center) clasps the hands of his daughter, Margaret, and her fiancé, New York newspaperman E. Clifton Daniel, Jr., at La Guardia Airport in New York City on March 16, 1956. Mr. Truman arrived for an overnight visit during which he will have a "quiet dinner" with the couple. The wedding is scheduled for April 21st in Independence, Missouri. (See also 77-3779.) This is a 14" x 16" oversize photo mounted on heavy card stock. From: Office of Harry Truman.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Escorts Daughter Margaret in Her Wedding Dress
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (left) escorts his daughter Margaret (right), in her wedding dress, from the Truman home to a car on the way to the Trinity Episcopal Church in Independence, Missouri.  (Similar to 82-21-1)  This is oversize photo mounted on heavy card stock.  From:  Office of President Truman.

title: President Truman on the Stairs of the "Independence"
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman waves his hat as he stands on the stairs of the presidential airplane Independence.  This is a 9-1/2" x 16" oversize photo mounted on heavy card stock.  From:  Office of President Truman.

title: Christmas card from Orval Faubus
Scopenote: Seasons Greetings Christmas card from Orval Faubus, Governor of Arkansas and former 35th Division member. The signature on the card reads "Orval, Alta & Farrell Faubus," but it is not known who actually signed the card. From: Unknown.

title: President Truman in Manchester, New Hampshire
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman is shown side-view at the podium as he campaigns for the Democratic nominee for President in Manchester, New Hampshire, during his New England tour. (Similar to 95-388) From: Ed Farlie, the South Bergen News, Rutherford, N.J.

title: President Truman and Margaret in Manchester, New Hampshire
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman waves to a crowd in Manchester, New Hampshire, during his New England tour while campaigning for the Democratic presidential candidate.  The President's daughter, Margaret, is behind him to the right.  The other people are unidentified.  (See also 2002-218 and 95-388.)  From:  Ed Farlie, The South Bergen News, Rutherford, N. J.

title: President Truman addresses the citizens of Eldorado, Illinois
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman addresses the citizens of Eldorado, Illinois, during a campaign trip through southern Illinois.  (See also album - 67-469 through 67-483)  From:  Mrs. John D. Upchurch, wife of John D. Upchurch, candidate for House of Representatives.

title: President Truman and Winston Churchill on train
Scopenote: President Truman and Winston Churchill (right) on the rear platform of the B&O Presidential Special as it arrives in Jefferson City, Missouri, en route to Westminster College in Fulton, Missouri, where they will be presented with honorary degrees. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill and President Truman in Motorcade in Fulton, Missouri
Scopenote: Surrounded by the Secret Service, Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill (right at back of car) waves from the back of an open automobile to the crowd lining the streets of Fulton, Missouri. He is on his way to Westminster College where he and President Truman, left at back of car, are to receive honorary degrees this date. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill and President Truman in Motorcade in Fulton, Missouri
Scopenote: Surrounded by the Secret Service, Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill, waves from the back of an open automobile to the crowd lining the streets of Fulton, Missouri, on his way to Westminster College where he and President Truman, sitting to Mr. Churchill's left, are to receive honorary degrees this date. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill and Harry S. Truman Ride in Car
Scopenote: Surrounded by the Secret Service, Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill (right), and President Harry S. Truman sit on the back seat of an open automobile in a parade from Jefferson City en route to Fulton, Missouri, where both will be presented honorary degrees from Westminster College. In the center seat are Phil M. Donnelly (left), Governor of the State of Missouri, and Admiral William Leahy. In the back seat is Dr. Franc McCluer, the president of Westminster College. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill and President Truman in Car in Jefferson City, Missouri
Scopenote: Surrounded by the Secret Service, Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill (left), and President Harry S. Truman, smile from the back seat of an open automobile in a parade from Jefferson City en route to Fulton, Missouri, where both will be presented with honorary degrees from Westminster College. Visible in profile is Phil M. Donnelly, Governor of the State of Missouri. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: People gathered to see Winston Churchill and President Truman in Jefferson City, Missouri
Scopenote: A view of some of the people gathered to see Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill, and President Harry S. Truman in a motorcade from Jefferson City where they arrived on the Presidential Special train en route to Fulton, Missouri, where both will be presented with honorary degrees from Westminster College.  From:  Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill and President Truman on Campus at Westminster College
Scopenote: Surrounded by the Secret Service, Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill (right), and President Harry S. Truman are photographed walking on the campus of Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, where both are to be presented with honorary degrees this date.  Visible behind the two men is Phil M. Donnelly, Governor of the State of Missouri.  (See also 65-3169.)  From:  Hathon M. Fields.

title: Winston Churchill, Harry S. Truman, and others in Fulton, Missouri
Scopenote: Left to right: Phil M. Donnelly, Governor of the State of Missouri; Winston Churchill, former Prime Minister of Great Britain; President Harry S. Truman; and Dr. Franc McCluer, President of Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, pose for a photograph on the campus of Westminster College. President Truman and Mr. Churchill are to be awarded honorary degrees this date. (See also 65-3169.) From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Photograph of former President Truman at the Carlyle Hotel in New York City
Scopenote: Photograph of an older Harry S. Truman at the Carlyle Hotel in New York City talking with various reporters after one of his famous "constitutional" walks.  The photograph is somewhat unique in that it is reflected in a mirror producing an interesting double view of the President.  From:  S. D. Uslan, President, Avalon Communications, Inc.

title: Phil M. Donnelly (left) and Admiral William Leahy at Westminster College
Scopenote: Phil M. Donnelly (left), Governor of Missouri, and Admiral William Leahy shake hands on the steps of the residence of Dr. Franc McCluer, President of Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri.  Both men accompanied President Truman and Winston Churchill on the trip to Westminster College where Truman and Churchill are to be awarded honorary degrees.  (See also 65-3160.)  From:  Hathon M Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: President Harry S. Truman and Britain's former Prime Minister Winston Churchill at Westminster College
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (right) waves his hat and Britain's former Prime Minster Winston Churchill (left) signs "V" for victory from the front porch of the residence of Dr. Franc McCluer, President of Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, where the two are to receive honorary degrees this date. Dr. McCluer is directly behind Mr. Churchill. The woman is unidentified. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: President Harry S. Truman and Winston Churchill at Westminster College
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (right) waves his hat to the crowd as Winston Churchill (center), Britain's former Prime Minster, enjoys one of his famous cigars while standing on the front porch of the residence of Dr. Franc McCluer, President of Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, where the two are to receive honorary degrees this date.  Phil M. Donnelly, Governor of the state of Missouri, is at left.  Dr. Franc McCluer is directly behind Mr. Churchill.  The woman is unidentified.  From:  Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: President Harry S. Truman and Britain's former Prime Minister Winston Churchill at Westminster College
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman stands at the podium during the playing of the National Anthem prior to introducing Britain's former Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who is the main speaker.  Both he and Mr. Churchill are to receive honorary degrees from Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, this date.  Mr. Churchill is on the President's left, and Dr. Franc McCluer, President of Westminster College, is on his right.  Behind the President on the left is Brig. General Harry Vaughan and on the right is Phil M. Donnelly, Governor of the state of Missouri.  The other men are unidentified.

title: Distance View of Winston Churchill at the Podium at Westminster College
Scopenote: Winston Churchill, Britain's former Prime Minster, stands at the podium where he will deliver his famous "Iron Curtain" speech at Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, where both he and President Harry S. Truman will receive honorary degrees this date. President Truman is sitting directly behind the podium to Churchill's left. Others able to be identified are Dr. Franc McCluer, President of Westminster College, in the front row to Churchill's right. In the second row, behind Mr. Churchill, is Brig. General Harry Vaughan. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill, Delivering his Famous "Iron Curtain" Speech
Scopenote: Winston Churchill, Britain's former Prime Minister, stands at the podium delivering his famous "Iron Curtain" speech at Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, where both he and President Harry S. Truman are to receive degrees this date. President Truman is not visible but is sitting directly behind Mr. Churchill. The others are unidentified. From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill Delivering his Famous "Iron Curtain" Speech
Scopenote: Winston Churchill, Britain's former Prime Minster, stands at the podium delivering his famous "Iron Curtain" speech at Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, where both he and President Truman are to receive honorary degrees this date.  From:  Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: President Truman Receives Honorary Degree from Westminster College
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman receives an honorary degree from Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, which was presented by Dr. Franc McCluer (right), President of the College.  President Truman made the trip to Fulton with Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill, who also received an honorary degree and who gave his famous "Iron Curtain" speech the same day.  The other man (at left)is unidentified.  From:  Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Winston Churchill at Westminster College
Scopenote: Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill (center), is congratulated by Dr. Franc McCluer (right), President of Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, where he and President Harry Truman have just been presented with honorary degrees.  The other man is unidentified.  From:  Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Truman and Winston Churchill Receive Honorary Degrees from Westminster College
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (center) and Great Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill, stand behind the podium after having received honorary degrees from Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri.  On the far right is Dr. Franc McCluer, President of the College.  Winston Churchill also made his famous "Iron Curtain" speech this date.  Clark Clifford and Harry Vaughan are in the background.  From:  Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Informal portrait of former President Truman at Mutual Broadcasting System conference
Scopenote: Informal portrait of former President Harry S. Truman taken at a Mutual Broadcasting System conference. This photograph contains the following original autograph: "To my boss, my friend, and still my President, Harry S. Truman, a great American. Bill Hillman, Independence Mo., July 1, 1958."

title: President Harry S. Truman and Winston Churchill at Westminster College
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (third from left) and Britain's former Prime Minister (right), stand behind the podium after having received honorary degrees from Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri.  Standing behind President Truman is Clark Clifford (left) and Brig. General Harry Vaughan (second from left).    From:  Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Court Street Methodist Church Ladies Prepare Meal for Ceremonies at Westminster College
Scopenote: The Court Street Methodist Church ladies are shown preparing for the multitude that would swarm into town for ceremonies at Westminster College where President Harry S. Truman and Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill, are to be awarded honorary degrees. Cooks from all over Callaway County had been pressed into service. The star of the menu was Callaway County ham. Churchill relished the meal. He solemnly proclaimed, "The pig has reached its highest point of evolution in this ham!" From: Hathon M. Fields, Independence, Missouri.

title: Mrs. Franc McCluer was Hostess of Luncheon at Westminster College
Scopenote: Mrs. Franc McCluer, wife of Dr. Franc McCluer, President of Westminster College, was hostess for a luncheon given in honor of President Harry S. Truman and Britain's former Prime Minister, Winston Churchill. Both men received honorary degrees from the College. Cooks from all over Callaway County had been pressed into service. The star of the menu was Callaway County ham. Churchill relished the meal. He solemnly proclaimed, "The pig has reached its highest point of evolution in this ham!" From: Hathon M. Fields.

title: Young Harry Vaughan in a Football Uniform
Scopenote: Photograph of a teen-age or young-adult Harry Vaughan in a football uniform.  The photo is printed on the back of post card and autographed "Harry Vaughan." Harry Vaughan later became a military aide and friend to President Truman.  From:  Mrs. Frank E. Fitzgerald.

title: Photo Portrait of Captain Harry Vaughan
Scopenote: This is a portrait of Captain Harry Vaughan in his World War I uniform, taken in St. Louis, Missouri.  From:  Mrs. Frank F. Fitzgerald.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman and Former Postmaster General James A. Farley
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (right) breakfasts with an old political crony, former Postmaster General James A. Farley at New York's Waldorf Astoria, February 4, 1956. Mr. Truman has been in New York for several days of active politicking and leaves for Boston later in the day for a major speech there. The picture is autographed: "To Hon Harry S. Truman(,) With sincere admiration(,) from his friend James A. Farley." Mr. Farley is now Chairman of the Board of the Coca-Cola Export Corporation. From: James A. Farley.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman in Miami, Florida
Scopenote: 5" x 6" black-and-white photograph of former President Harry S. Truman taken in Miami, Florida, ca. 1950s, in front of the McAllister Hotel, Biscayne Blvd., Miami, Florida. The man on the right is unidentified. The photographer, Warren G. Fisher, was a former staff photographer at Miami Life newspaper and freelance photographer at The Miami Herald. From: Ms. Eileen Fisher.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman in Miami, Florida
Scopenote: 5" x 6" black-and-white photograph of former President Harry S. Truman (center) taken in Miami, Florida, ca 1950's in front of the McAllister Hotel, Biscayne Blvd., Miami, Florida.  The other two men are unidentified.  The photographer, Warren G.  Fisher, was a former staff photographer at Miami Life newspaper and freelance photographer at The Miami Herald.  (See also 2002-247 and 249.)  From: Ms. Eileen Fisher.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman in Miami, Florida
Scopenote: 5" x 6" black-and-white photograph of former President Harry S. Truman (left) shaking hands with an unidentified man as he passes by the President. The photo was taken in Miami, Florida, ca. 1950's, in front of the McAllister Hotel, Biscayne Blvd., Miami, Florida. The other two men are also unidentified. The photographer, Warren G. Fisher, was a former staff photographer at Miami Life newspaper and freelance photographer at the Miami Herald. (See also 2002-247 and 248.) From: Ms. Eileen Fisher.

title: Photograph of President Truman at Mutual Broadcasting System Conference
Scopenote: Photograph of President Harry S. Truman taken at a Mutual Broadcasting System conference.   William Hillman is seated third from left.  See also 2002-24.  William Hillman is the author of the book "Mr. President," published in 1952.

title: Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson, John Snyder, and Edward H. Foley, Jr
Scopenote: Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson (right) swears in Edward H. Foley, Jr. (left), as Under Secretary of Treasury on July 15, 1948, at 4:30 P.M.  Secretary of Treasury John Snyder is second from the right.  The woman is unidentified.

title: President Truman and Margaret on the Platform of a Train in Belton, Montana
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman and his daughter, Margaret, stand on the platform of a train as it made a brief stop at the Great Northern Depot in Belton, Montana, during a campaign trip for the Democratic ticket of Stevenson and Sparkman.  From:  Wallace Floren.

title: President Truman and Margaret Wave from a Train in Belton, Montana
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman and his daughter, Margaret, wave from the platform of a train as it makes a brief stop at the Great Northern Depot in Belton, Montana, during a campaign trip for the Democratic ticket of Stevenson and Sparkman.  The unidentified men are agents of the Secret Service.  From:  Wallace Floren.

title: President Truman speaks from the Platform of a Train in Belton, Montana
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman speaks from the platform of a train as it makes a brief stop at the Great Northern Depot in Belton, Montana, during a campaign trip for the Democratic ticket of Stevenson and Sparkman.  From:  Wallace Floren.

title: President Truman on Platform of Train in Belton, Montana
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman is greeted by an unidentified woman as he stands on the platform of a train making a brief stop at the Great Northern Depot in Belton, Montana, during a campaign trip for the Democratic ticket of Stevenson and Sparkman.  From:  Wallace Floren.

title: Color Photograph of Russian Building Where Truman Bust was Exhibited
Scopenote: Color photograph of building in Russia where the Belsky Bust of President Truman, sculpted by Franta Belsky of England, was on display during the United States Information Agency's Bicentennial Exhibition in 1976.  From:  U. S. Information Agency.

title: President Truman Signing Public Housing Bill
Scopenote: President Truman in the oval office signed into law the controversial Public Housing and Slum-Clearance Bill--the first of his so-called "Fair Deal" measures to be approved by Congress.  Looking on as the Chief Executive affixed his signature, left to right:  Senator Burnet R. Maybank (with his head turned) (D.S.C.); Senator Ralph E. Flanders (R. Vt.); Senator John J. Sparkman (D. Ala); Raymond M. Foley, Federal Housing Administrator; Brent Spence (D. Ky.); and James E. Carey, Secretary-Treasurer of the CIO.  The other men are unidentified.  (See also 66-2306.)

title: Portrait of General J. Lawton Collins
Scopenote: Portrait of General J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, who met with President Harry S. Truman on October 4, 1949, at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, when the President visited this installation to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.

title: Photograph of the Aeronca L16B airplane
Scopenote: Aerial photograph of the Aeronca L16B (SN 48-430) airplane in flight taken near Middleton, Ohio, where it was manufactured. This view shows Franklin, Ohio, and the Great Miami River in the background. This high-wing, two-place liaison plane was manufactured by the Aeronca Aircraft Corporation of Middletown, Ohio. Over 600 are in use by the Army Field Forces and National Guard. This is an example of one of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October 4, 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.

title: Photograph of the Piper L-4 Grasshopper
Scopenote: A propeller plane parked on the tarmac, the Piper L-4 "Grasshopper." This airplane, used by the Army Ground Forces for artillery spotting, liaison work, and transporting of personnel, is manufactured by the Piper Aircraft Corporation, Lock Haven, Pennsylvania. Its short landing and take-off characteristics permit its use on small, unprepared fields or roads. This is an example of planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October 4, 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.

title: Autographed photograph of painting of Truman by Augustus Vincent Tack
Scopenote: Autographed photograph of a painting of Harry S. Truman seated at a desk by Augustus Vincent Tack.  The picture is autographed by Augustus Vincent Tack "To my dear Mr. Truman with deepest appreciation for his generous cooperation."

title: Photograph of the Boeing YL-15 Scout
Scopenote: The Boeing YL-15 Scout was one of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October 4, 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons. The plane shown here was photographed in flight during the initial stages of the extensive service testing program now being conducted on the versatile liaison plane by the Army Field Forces and the Air Force. It was manufactured by the Boeing Airplane Company, Wichita, Kansas Division, photo no. BW-40421.

title: Photograph of the Bell H-13B Helicopter
Scopenote: View of a Bell-built H-13B helicopter in flight with two occupants. This is an example of one of the helicopters viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, on October 4, 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons. This helicopter is used by the Army Field Forces for a variety of serial assignments, including liaison, fire control, wire laying, transport and evacuation and is manufactured by the Bell Aircraft Corporation, Buffalo, NY.

title: Photograph of Two Convair L-13 Planes
Scopenote: Composite photo of two Convair L-13 planes, one in flight and one landing on the water with floats. These are examples of planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons. The all-metal, all-purpose Convair L-13, built at San Diego by Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation. At the time of viewing, Consolidated Vultee was studying a proposed engine change from a 245-horsepower Franklin engine to a newly designed Continental air-cooled engine rated at 285-hp.

title: Boeing YL-15 Scout Loaded into a C-97 Stratofreighter
Scopenote: A Boeing YL-15 Scout airplane being loaded into a Boeing C-97 Stratofreighter on the tarmac of an unknown airfield. These are examples of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons. Four Scouts, 30 air-and-ground crew members, plus all necessary spares and equipment for an Army Field Forces operating liaison unit can be transported with ease in a giant Stratofreighter. It is necessary to remove only the wheels and 16 bolts from the body structure. They were manufactured by the Boeing Airplane Company, Wichita, Kansas, photo number BW-37861.

title: Fairchild Packet C-82 Airplane in Flight
Scopenote: Aerial view of the Fairchild Packet C-82 airplane in flight. This is an example of one of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons. The chief use of the Fairchild Packet C-82 is the transporting of troops and cargo.

title: Montage Photograph of a Fairchild Packet C-82 Airplane
Scopenote: Aerial views of a Fairchild Packett C-82 airplane in flight, as well as its interior. This is an example of one of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons. With the seats removed and the entire space utilized, the C-82 can carry a disposable load of 21,500 lbs. Rear doors open vertically on center-line, and adjustable ramps permit cargo to be driven in. At right, a 105 mm. Howitzer is shown ready for transport, and at bottom it is dislodged from the rear of the plane.

title: Parachutists step into space from a Fairchild C-82
Scopenote: Parachutists step into space from twin doors in the Fairchild C-82.  This maneuver took place at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949 during President Harry S. Truman's visit, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.  The C-82 was built by Fairchild Aircraft, Hagerstown, Maryland.

title: Parachutes From C-82 Airplanes
Scopenote: Parachutes dot the sky after parachutists step into space from Fairchild C-82 airplanes.   This maneuver took place at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949, to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.  The C-82 was built by Fairchild Aircraft, Hagerstown, Maryland.

title: Photograph of Interior of Fairchild Packet C-119
Scopenote: Photograph of the interior of a Fairchild Packet C-110, one of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949 to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.  The chief use of the Fairchild Packet C-119 is the transporting of troops and cargo.  This photo shows several automobiles which have been loaded into the airplane.

title: Photograph of Interior of Fairchild Packet C-82
Scopenote: Photograph of the interior of a Fairchild Packet C-82, showing a car being loaded into the plane.  The C-82 is one of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949 to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.

title: Korean War Veterans Memorial by Mac Adams
Scopenote: Color photograph of the Korean War Veterans Memorial by Mac Adams called "The Universal Soldier".  The memorial was dedicated on June 25, 1991, and is located in Battery Park, New York City.  The theme for the Korean Monument is reconciliation through the image of The Universal Soldier.  From:  Fred R. Tannery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Paratroopers of the 82nd Airborne Division at Fort Bragg
Scopenote: Paratroopers of the 82nd Airborne Division climb into their Fairchild Flying Boxcar (Fairchild C-82) during maneuvers at Fort Bragg, North Carolina.  Each man carries about 90 pounds  of equipment, including weapons and two parachutes.  The C-82 is one of the planes viewed by President Truman during his visit to  Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949 to review airborne maneuvers as well as to review 20,000 troops and inspect new artillery weapons.

title: Two U.S. Army Planes in Flight
Scopenote: Aerial view of two unidentified U S. Army planes in the air. The photo was included in a group of eighteen photographs of U.S. Air Force planes, helicopters, and paratroop demonstrations provided at the time of President Truman's visit of Fort Bragg, North Carolina, in October of 1949. This photo is likely an example of the kind of planes that President Truman viewed during the demonstration.

title: Portrait of Fred Wallace as Older Man
Scopenote: Portrait photograph of Fred Wallace, youngest brother of Madge Gates Wallace, as an older man.  From:  Eric Fowler.

title: Panoramic Photo of President Harry S. Truman Speaking at Auditorium in his Hometown
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (standing before microphones) speaks to an audience of nearly 10,000 persons in the auditorium of his hometown shortly after his arrival in Independence, Missouri. Returning from the U.S. Pacific coast city of San Francisco, where he addressed the closing session of the United Nations Conference, President Truman stopped for a short vacation with his family in Independence. Speaking to the people in his hometown, the Chief Executive said: "There are two things that I must accomplish as President of the United States. The first one is to win the war with Japan -- and we are winning it. The next one is to win a peace." President Truman continued: "The first step toward the winning of that peace has been accomplished in San Francisco." From: Eric Fowler.

title: President Harry S. Truman Speaks at RLDS Auditorium in Independence, MO
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (standing before microphones) speaks to an audience of nearly 10,000 persons in the auditorium of his hometown shortly after his arrival in Independence, Missouri.  Returning from San Francisco, where he addressed the closing session of the United Nations Conference on International Organization, President Truman stopped for a short vacation with his family in Independence.  Speaking to the people in his hometown, the American Chief Executive said:  "There are two things that I must accomplish as President of the United States.  The first one is to win the war with Japan -- and we are winning it.  The next one is to win a peace." President Truman continued: "The first step toward the winning of that peace has been accomplished in San Francisco."  From:  Eric Fowler.

title: Portrait of Nannie B. Willock Wallace

title: Snapshot of President Harry S. Truman addressing a crowd in Iowa

In Iowa, as elsewhere on the coast to coast whistlestop tour, the routine was the same:  Truman would come to the mike, say a few words, accept the cheers and "give 'em hell, Harry" shouts, and then say, "Now I want you to say hello to my greatest asset, my daughter Margaret."  Margaret would step out of the body of car onto the platform.  (Bess Truman was not on this trip.)  Donor:  Richard Cull, Jr.

title: Japanese officer signing documents in China
Scopenote: Japanese officer signing surrender documents at ceremonies in China marking the surrender of the Japanese to Allied forces.  The exact date, location, and identities of the individuals are unknown.  From:  Donald L. Jacobs - made available through Lennie Thacker, Commander of VFW Post 1000.

title: Presidential Airplane Independence
Scopenote: Photograph of the Presidential Airplane Independence sitting on an airstrip at an unidentified airport. The photo was obtained from the Air Force Museum, probably at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. From: Richard Cull, Jr.

title: Former President Truman and Leading Democrats
Scopenote: Photo of former President Harry S. Truman clasping the hands of other leading Democrats, taken at the "Black Tie" dinner during the 1960 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, California, in mid-July.  Left to right are:  G. Mennen Williams, Hubert Humphrey, Leroy Collins, former President Truman, John F. Kennedy, Pat Brown, and Stuart Symington.  From:  Frank Cullen, Jr., FCA Company, 2040 Avenue of the Stars, Los Angeles, California 90067.

title: Margaret Truman on Board the Liner President Cleveland
Scopenote: Photo of Margaret Truman (right) on board the liner President Cleveland, having just returned from a month's vacation in Hawaii with her mother and father.  The woman on the left is  unidentified. They are in San Francisco, California. (See 2002-462.)  From:  Frank Cullen, Sr.

title: Margaret Truman on Board the Liner President Cleveland
Scopenote: Photo of Margaret Truman (right) on board the liner President Cleveland, having just returned from a month's vacation in Hawaii with her mother and father. The other two women are unidentified. They are in San Francisco, California. (See also 2002-462.)  From:  Frank Cullen, Sr.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman with California Governor Pat Brown at Campaign Event
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (right foreground) speaks to California Governor Edmund "Pat" Brown (left of Mr. Truman) at the dais of the Palladium at the kick-off of the Governor's reelection campaign in Los Angeles, California. The band leader with the upraised hands in background is Lawrence Welk. The other men are unidentified. From: Frank Cullen, Sr., FCA Company, 2040 Avenue of the Stars, Los Angeles, California, 90067.

title: Japanese officer signing documents in China
Scopenote: Japanese officer signing documents at ceremonies in China marking the surrender of the Japanese to Allied forces.  The exact date, location, and identities are unknown.  From:  Donald L. Jacobs - made available through Lennie Thacker, Commander of VFW Post 1000.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman in the Fairmount Hotel in San Francisco
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (left) dines in the Tonga Room at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco, California, the night before the Trumans (wife and daughter) sail on the ship "President Cleveland" for a visit to Ed Pauley's estate in Hawaii.  An American President Lines Commodore is third from the right; however, his name and the identities of the others are unknown.  From:  Frank Cullen, Sr., FCA Company.

title: California Governor Edmund G. Brown
Scopenote: California Governor Edmund G. (Pat) Brown accepts the "Give 'em hell, Harry" award in Elk Grove, California, in 1985. From: Frank Cullen, Sr., FCA Company, 2040 Avenue of the Stars, Los Angeles, California, 90067.

title: Photo of Grave Stone in Cemetery in Elgin, Minnesota
Scopenote: Photo of a grave stone in a small cemetery in the town of Elgin, Minnesota, about 18 miles from Rochester.  On the base of the tombstone is engraved the following words:  "None of us ever voted for Roosevelt or Truman."  From:  Eugene W. Cutshall.

title: Winston Churchill and Harry S. Truman on Eve of Potsdam Conference
Scopenote: Official British war photograph (BU8944{X5} of Winston Churchill and President Harry S. Truman meeting on the eve of the Potsdam Conference on July 16, l945, at Truman's residence.  It was their first meeting since Mr. Truman became President. (Same as 66-1796 except better quality)  From:  Gary W. Davis.

title: Former President Truman Meets Rabbi Abraham Danzig and Harold Boxer in his office at Federal Reserve Bank
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman meets with Rabbi Abraham Danzig (left), Beth Israel-Abraham, and Harold Boxer (right), Flushing, New York National Vice President, Union Orthodox Jewish Congregations, at his office on the 11th floor of the Federal Reserve Bank Building, Kansas City, Missouri.  From:  Rabbi Abraham Danzig.

title: Former President Truman meets with Rabbi Abraham Danzig and Harold Boxer
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. From:  Rabbi Abraham Danzig.

title: President Truman in Motorcade in Miami Beach, Florida
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (left), wearing his American Legion hat, in a motorcade in Miami Beach, Florida.  He will be attending the National American Legion Convention in Miami.  The other two men are unidentified.  From:  Clifton Daniel, Jr. (sent to him from Jay E. Kashuk, Miami Beach, Florida.)

title: President Truman at Milton Academy in Quincy, Massachusetts
Scopenote: President Truman speaks at the Milton Academy in Quincy, Massachusetts.    From:  Frederick A. Davis, through Clifton Davis, Jr.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman at Reception for Bar Enrollees
Scopenote: Photograph of former President Harry S. Truman taken at the reception (coffee) for the Bar Enrollees in the office of John M. Dalton, Attorney General of Missouri, Jefferson City, Missouri.  The man on the left is unidentified.  From:  John M. Dalton, Attorney General of Missouri.

title: Snapshot of Movie Star Joe E. Brown
Scopenote: Snapshot of movie star Joe E. Brown dining with American servicemen.  The event, date, location, and names of the other people are unknown.  From:  Jack C. Davis.

title: Army Soldiers Riding in Military Vehicle
Scopenote: Snapshot of Army soldiers riding in a military vehicle on a city street, perhaps in a parade.  The event, date, and location unknown.  From:  Jack C. Davis.

title: Photograph of Painting of President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Black-and-white photograph of a painting of President Harry S. Truman by Frank Salisbury, which was on exhibition in Dallas, Texas, at the Dallas Museum of Fine Arts. (See also 60-325-7)  From:  Dallas Museum of Fine Arts, P. O. Box 7965, Dallas 26, Texas.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman and Bess Truman on Trip to Bermuda
Scopenote: Snapshot of Former President Harry S. Truman and Bess Truman taken as they stand on the deck of the Queen of Bermuda during their trip to Bermuda. (See also 96-162-1 through 10.) From: Gladys P. Cullom.

title: Color Photograph of Statue of Former President Harry S. Truman Sculpted by Richard Head
Scopenote: Color photograph of a statue of former President Harry S. Institutional Creator: Chamber of Commerce and Culver-Stockton College

title: Warren E. Hearnes, Governor of Missouri, at Culver-Stockton College
Scopenote: Warren E. Hearnes, Governor of Missouri, speaks at the unveiling of a statue of former President Harry S. Truman which officially opened the Avenue of the Missourians at Culver-Stockton College in Canton, Missouri.  The sculptor is Richard Head.  The other people are unidentified.

title: Portrait of Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Portrait of Harry S. Truman (streak at top of image) attached to backing, with the following inscription on the backing:  "Best wishes to Hal Oustolt (spelling in question) from his friend, Harry S. Truman, USS Mo." (Original in oversize file)  From:  Unknown - Found in old audiovisual area.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman on Walk in Washington, D. C
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (center) takes an early morning walk past the National Presbyterian Church, where President Eisenhower attends services.  The former President who is on a four-day visit to Washington, D. C., will attend a dinner honoring Speaker of the House Sam Rayburn.  Flanked by reporters, Mr. Truman walked for half an hour. (Similar to 69-545)  From:  Morris Cunningham, Scripps-Howard Newspaper Alliance, Washington, D. C.

title: Five unidentified soldiers standing in Front of the Truman House
Scopenote: Snapshot of five unidentified soldiers standing before the front porch of the Truman house in Independence, Missouri. On the back of the picture is written:  "Harry Truman's front porch -- remember?"  From:  Mrs. C. L. Jones.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman with Charles F. Curry
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (right) talks with Charles F. Curry, Kansas City businessman and friend, at Mr. Truman's office in the Federal Reserve Bank Building, Kansas City, Missouri.  On the back of the photograph, in Mr. Truman's hand, is the following:  "Charles Curry on an office visit.  H.S.T."  From:  Charles F. Curry

title: Color Photograph of Truman House in Independence, Missouri
Scopenote: Exceptional color photograph of the Truman house at 219 N. Delaware, Independence Missouri, taken late afternoon, November 11, 1959, showing two sides of the house.  From:  Rolfe B. Dean.

title: Color Photograph of Truman Library
Scopenote: Color photograph of the front view of the Harry S. Truman Library in Independence, Missouri, taken the morning of November 12, 1959.  From:  Rolfe B. Dean.

title: The Truman Birthplace in Lamar, Missouri
Scopenote: Front view of the house in Lamar, Missouri, where President Truman was born, showing a handprinted "admission" sign on the front porch, probably taken before restoration and dedication were accomplished.  This photograph appears on Page 156 in the book "Mr. President" by William Hillman.  From:  Papers of William Hillman, "Mr. President" file, Box 2 - Loose Dummy (2 of 2).

title: Color Photograph of Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Color photograph of former President Harry S. Truman sitting at his private secretary's (Rose Conway) desk at the Harry S. Truman Library, doing a requested signing of a Scottish Rite Patent. The picture was taken the morning of November 12, 1959. From: Rolfe B. Dean.

title: Sergeant William Story at Grand Piano in the Truman Library
Scopenote: Color photograph of Sergeant William Story, guard at the Harry S. Truman Library, sitting at the grand piano that was in the White House during the Truman administration.  The picture was taken at the Library the morning of November 12, 1959.  From:  Rolfe B. Dean.

Scopenote: J. Vivian Truman with his wife Luella Truman seated in front of a radio in their house (similar to 78-912). title: Former President Truman Arriving by Plane in Tennessee
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (second from left) being greeted by three unidentified men after arriving by plane in Nashville, Tennessee during his campaign for John F. Kennedy.  Mr. Truman spoke to 5,000 people at Freed Stadium in Trenton, Tennessee, urging them to return to the Democratic fold.  He delivered a fighting speech in Trenton, Tennessee, inviting Tennesseans to join his native Missouri in electing Democrat Sen. John F. Kennedy, Jr.  The picture is autographed as follows:  "Kind regards, Harry S. Truman - 11-15-60."  From:  Tennessee Executive Office, Nashville, Tennessee.

title: Harry S. Truman receives a certificate relating to the American Royal
Scopenote: Harry S. Truman (left) receives a certificate appointing him Honorary Governor of the American Royal Association, Kansas City, Missouri.  The two men are unknown but are Governors of the American Royal.  (See also 2002-64.)

title: Former President Truman and the Board of Governors of American Royal Association
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (fifth from left, standing) and the Board of Governors of the American Royal Association, of which Mr. Truman has just been made an Honorary Governor.  The identities of the Governors are unknown.  (See also 2002-63.)

title: Photograph of a television set as President Harry S. Truman speaks
Scopenote: A photograph taken by a local Kansas City resident of a television set as President Harry S. Truman was addressing the nation. The time and event are unknown. From: Thompson, Kenneth

title: Close-up portrait of President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Portrait of President Harry S. Truman taken on June 19th, 1960, at the Carlyle Hotel in New York City by Arnold Newman. Another portrait taken that day by Arnold Newman appeared in Life magazine on July 4, 1960. From: Arnold Newman.

Scopenote: Photograph of statue of General Andrew Jackson, before the Jackson County Courthouse in Independence, with dedication:  "This statue presented to the people of Jackson County by Harry S. From:  Papers of William Hillman, "Mr. President" file, Box 2 Loose Dummy (2 of 2)

title: Winston Churchill and Harry S. Truman at Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri
Scopenote: Snapshot of Winston Churchill and Harry S. Truman in cap and gown taken at Westminster College, Fulton, Missouri, as a procession started from President McCluer's home on campus to the gymnasium where Sir Winston Churchill made his famous "Iron Curtain" speech. Directly behind President Truman is General Harry Vaughan. From: C. Owen Taylor.

Scopenote: President Truman departs by automobile from Pittston on his way to Scranton, Pennsylvania, after attending the 42nd Annual Dinner of the Friendly Sons of Saint Patrick of Greater Pittston, Pennsylvania. title: A four-engine German transport plane, the Junkers 290
Scopenote: A four-engine German transport plane, the Junkers 290, lands at Patterson Field, Dayton, Ohio - the first of such type to reach the United States.  The captured plane will be studied by the Air Technical Service Command.  From:  Pershing Tousley, Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.

title: President Truman and Harvey S. Firestone, Jr. with U.S.O. Flag
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (left) receives the first new red, white, and blue flag of the newly reorganized United Service Organization from businessman Harvey S.
